item.title: Android
item.description:
The Zest Android app is built with Jetpack Compose.

Tech Stack

  • Language: Kotlin
  • UI: Jetpack Compose with Material 3 Expressive
  • Architecture: MVVM + Clean Architecture
  • Dependency Injection: Hilt

Getting Started

  1. Open the android directory in Android Studio.
  2. Set up Firebase:
    • Download the google-services.json file from your Firebase project’s settings.
    • Place the google-services.json file in the android/app directory.
  3. Build and run the app on an emulator or a physical device.

Testing

The Android app includes unit tests and instrumentation tests. You can run these tests from Android Studio.

item.title: Backend
item.description:
The Zest backend is built on Firebase.

Services

  • Authentication: Firebase Authentication is used to manage user accounts.
  • Database: Firestore is used as the primary database for storing recipes, meal plans, and other user data.
  • Storage: Firebase Storage is used to store recipe images and other user-generated content.

Offline Support

Firestore’s local persistence is enabled on all platforms to provide a seamless offline experience.

Security

Firebase Security Rules are used to secure the data in Firestore and Firebase Storage. These rules are defined in the firestore.rules and storage.rules files.

item.title: Getting Started
item.description:
This guide will help you get up and running with Zest.

Installation

Zest is available on the following platforms:

  • Web: Access the Zest web app directly from your browser.
  • iOS: Download the Zest app from the App Store.
  • Android: Download the Zest app from the Google Play Store.

Creating an Account

To get the most out of Zest, you’ll need to create an account. This will allow you to save your favorite recipes, create meal plans, and more.

item.title: iOS
item.description:
The Zest iOS app is built with SwiftUI.

Tech Stack

  • Language: Swift
  • UI: SwiftUI with a custom “Liquid Glass” design language
  • Architecture: MVVM
  • Frameworks: Combine

Getting Started

  1. Open the ios/Zest.xcworkspace file in Xcode.
  2. Set up Firebase:
    • Download the GoogleService-Info.plist file from your Firebase project’s settings.
    • Place the GoogleService-Info.plist file in the ios/Zest directory.
  3. Build and run the app on a simulator or a physical device.

Testing

The iOS app includes unit tests and UI tests. You can run these tests from Xcode.

item.title: Meal Planner
item.description:
The meal planner is a powerful tool that helps you organize your meals for the week.

Adding Recipes to Your Meal Plan

To add a recipe to your meal plan, follow these steps:

  1. Find the recipe you want to add.
  2. On the recipe detail screen, tap the “Add to Meal Plan” button.
  3. Select the day and meal (breakfast, lunch, or dinner) for which you want to schedule the recipe.

Viewing Your Meal Plan

You can view your meal plan by tapping on the “Meal Plan” tab. This will show you a calendar view of your scheduled meals for the week. You can tap on any meal to see the recipe details.

item.description:

  • Filter: You can filter the recipe list by cuisine and difficulty to narrow down your options.

item.title: Shopping List
item.description:
The shopping list feature helps you keep track of the ingredients you need to buy for your planned meals.

Generating a Shopping List

You can generate a shopping list from your meal plan or from a single recipe.

  • From your meal plan: Go to the “Meal Plan” tab and tap the “Generate Shopping List” button. This will create a shopping list with all the ingredients you need for the week’s meals.
  • From a recipe: On the recipe detail screen, tap the “Add to Shopping List” button. This will add the ingredients for that recipe to your shopping list.

item.title: Web
item.description:
The Zest web app is built with Next.js and React.

Tech Stack

  • Framework: Next.js 14 with React 18 (App Router)
  • Language: TypeScript
  • Styling: Tailwind CSS with a custom Material 3 Expressive design system.
  • State Management: Zustand
  • Data Fetching: Firebase SDK
  • Testing:
    • Unit/Integration: Vitest and React Testing Library
    • E2E: Playwright

Getting Started

  1. Navigate to the web directory: 
    cd web
  2. Install dependencies: 
    npm install
  3. Set up Firebase:
    • Create a .env.local file in the web directory.
    • Add your Firebase project’s credentials to the .env.local file. See web/.env.example for an example.
  4. Run the development server: 
    npm run dev

Building and Running for Production

  • Create a production build: npm run build
  • Start the production server: npm run start

Testing

  • Run unit tests: npm test
  • Run E2E tests: npx playwright test
